intro.text: Climate resiliency through the eyes of Redband Trout
intro.alt: Illustration of the Donner und Blitzen landscape, showing sage-brush bluffs surrounding a river valley.

intro.text: Welcome to the Donner und Blitzen River in Eastern Oregon. This is a beautiful river basin surrounded by the Blue Mountains to the north and lava plains to the south. Alpine headwater streams combine and eventually feed into the larger river in the main valley.

Land managers like these three work together to care for the natural resources in the river basin. They monitor plants and animals, fish health and behavior, and landscape conditions to help increase resiliency as the climate changes.

They each use different approaches to manage the land and together follow the R.A.D. framework of land management. R stands for Resist, as in resisting future climate conditions. A is for Accept, as in accepting climate change affects on plants and animals. And D is for Direct, where managers directly shape the landscape toward preferred new conditions.

Denise monitors an area of the river that is a common spawning location for Redband Trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss newberrii). Redband Trout live in the rivers of the Donner und Blitzen River basin. As they grow up, they migrate to connected streams and lakes to live. Then, as adults, they return each year to their original hatching grounds to spawn.

Newly hatched Redband Trout are called alevins, with a yolk sac to keep them fed until they're bigger. These two are cousins, and they share many of the same genetic traits. They are also able to adapt to their local conditions through a process called acclimation, which is when organisms become accustom to their surroundings, such as water temperature.

After they get big enough to leave the nest, these two Redband Trout migrate to other areas of the river basin to grow up. One migrates upstream to the headland waters, while the other goes downstream to the main river valley. As they grow, they acclimate to the water temperatures in their new homes.​

Randy monitors and manages the headwaters area, where water temperature is colder than the spawning grounds. This particular headwater stream is spring-fed, rocky, and clear. This Redband Trout, which is now a fry (juvenile trout), settles into its new habitat, adjusts to the cooler temperatures, and eats a diet of water insects and nymphs.

This young fish has grown in size and has adapted to the cold headwaters. Its adult bodysize is limited by the size of the river, as fish sizes relate to river size (less room, lower productivity, and less food than large rivers).

Because it has grown up in the cold headwaters, this fish is cold-adapted. That means that it has a narrow optimal temperature range, and that it can quickly become stressed when stream temperatures increase, which is happening more often in the summers because of climate change.

Randy Resists the rising summer temperatures by planting more trees along the headwater streams. This increases shade and slows down how fast the river heats up. This improves the habitat for the cold-adapted fish in these headwater streams.
intro.alt: Complex landscape illustration showing alpine river in the upper left and valley river in the lower right. Mike and Barry have both grown up into full-size fish. They're sending a letter to each other to keep in touch.

intro.text: Meanwhile, the other Redband Trout fry has migrated downstream to the main river valley. This area of the river is monitored by Alex and is bustling with life. The warmer waters bring more productivity, plant life, and food for the fish in the rivers.
This Redband Trout has taken advantage of the productive river and has grown larger than its upstream counterpart.

It also is warm-adapted, meaning it has a wider optimal temperature range and can handle warmer summer temperatures. However, as the climate changes summer temperatures could start to get too hot even for these warm-adapteed fish, causing stress.

This fish has now reached its young adult size and is getting ready to migrate back to its spawning grounds as winter turns into spring. Unfortunately, there has also been an invasion of common carp, which is a bottom feeder that uproots vegetation and creates cloudy water conditions. This stresses the native fish like this Redband Trout.

While Alex Accepts that climate and ecosystems are changing, she can help reduce stress for native fish like the Redband Trout by removing invasive species, reducing harm from fishing by banning barbed hooks, and promoting catch-and-release for Redband Trout.

It is now spring, and both fish are at their adult sizes and are preparing to migrate back to the spawning grounds to spawn for the first time. Unfortunately this winter did not have as much snowfall as normal, and spring has brought lower-than-average rainfall. There is a drought, which are occurring more and more often.
Because of the drought, some of the common waterways that Redband Trout would have used to migrate to their spawning grounds are dried up and impassable.

Fortunately, Denise is monitoring the landscape and can Direct the ecosystem to become more resilient by creating more connectivity between streams, digging new channels, and removing dams. Both fish are able to return to their spawning grounds and give rise to the next generation of alevins.
By working together to manage the system as a whole, all three of the approaches to land management (Resist, Accept, Direct) improve the landscape for generations to come.

hotWater.text: Barry suggests that Mike move to his part of the river, where the waters run warmer than other parts of the area.
hotWater.alt: Close up of the warm river stream with Mike and Barry swimming in the water. Mike says, Wow, your home is really bustling with life! Barry replies, Yeah! Here in my home you will find lots of food and warmth.

hotWater.text: Barry begins to notice that Mike is not doing well in their new home. While things are easy for Barry, Mike is finding it very difficult to adjust.
hotWater.alt: Mike looks stressed by the heat and is swimming limply. Barry looks less happy and says, Oh no Mike, you are looking green around the gills.

hotWater.text: In hot waters, cold-adapted fish suffer greatly and can even die.
hotWater.alt: Landscape view of the same river with a data visualization showing the growth rates of cold-adapted fish and warm-adapted fish. In these hot temperatures, the warm-adapted fish can grow but the cold-adapted fish suffer and can even die.

hotWater.text: As waters warm from climate change, this can put stress on native fish. Alex decides to accept these changes, and redirects her energy into reducing stress to native species from aspects they can control, like fishing and invasive species.
hotWater.alt: Landscape view of the same river with Alex standing near the shore holding a sign that indicates a ban on fishing.

warmWater.text: Mike and Barry decide they want to go somewhere new for them both, for a fresh start. They pick out a new spot in the watershed – warmer than Mike’s old stream but cooler than Barry’s old stream.
warmWater.alt: Mike and Barry swimming together in a stream that is between the cold and hot streams. Mike says, So... do you like it here? Barry replies unenthusiastically, um, sure. You? Mike hesitantly replies, yeah, for sure...

warmWater.text: While Mike is growing with the warmer temperature and roomier habitat, he finds that it's a bit too warm, and that Barry is not doing as well in this new habitat.
warmWater.alt: Mike and Barry both secretly thinking I miss home.

warmWater.text: In these moderate temperatures, both cold-adapted and warm-adapted fish can grow, but with the larger, warmer streams the small, cold-adapted fish grow at a higher pace than larger, warm-adapted fish.
warmWater.alt: Landscape view of the same river with a data visualization showing the growth rates of cold-adapted fish and warm-adapted fish. In these moderate temperatures, the both fish can survive, but the growth rate decreases slightly as temperatures warm.

warmWater.text: Denice notices some streams are warming and may not be as good for native fish. To help, she works to increase connections between parts of the river to reduce impacts from drought and help plants and animals adapt.
warmWater.alt: Landscape view of the same river with a cartoon Denise manager standing next to the river with a shovel and bucket of dirt.

coldWater.text: Mike suggests that Barry move to his part of the river, where the waters run colder than other parts of the area.
coldWater.alt: Zoomed in illustration of the cold stream with Mike and Barry swimming together. Mike says with a big grin on his face, welcome to my home, friend! Barry secretly thinks brr...

coldWater.text: It doesn’t take long to notice that warm-adapted Barry can’t tolerate these cold streams, even though the cold-adapted Mike feels just fine.
coldWater.alt: After they're in the stream for a while, Barry gets very cold and has put on a scarf and is shivering. Mike notices and says with a concerned expression, Yikes, Barry, you don't look so hot...

coldWater.text: In cold waters, cold-adapted fish grow better than warm-adapted fish.
coldWater.alt: Landscape view of the same river with a data visualization showing the growth rates of cold-adapted fish and warm-adapted fish. In these cold temperatures, cold-adapted fish grow at a higher rate than warm-adapted fish.

coldWater.text: Randy notices smaller trout do well in the cold waters, but waters in the area are warming due to climate change. He decides to resist these future changes by planting trees on stream edges to provide cooling shade to the river.
coldWater.alt: Landscape view of the same river with Randy standing near the bank with his arms crossed. He's got tree seedlings to plant along the bank with him.

outro.text: Mike and Barry both decide that there's no place like home, and part ways. However, they promise to keep in touch from their home streams.
outro.alt: Illustration of the Donner und Blitzen landscape, showing sage-brush bluffs surrounding a river valley.
